Packages.Name: All objects
Packages.Description: Exports all objects & types of the project

Properties.Text:
Oh, hell, how does this thing work?...

Hello?

Oh...

This is great! I can see what I’m saying on the screen!

I don’t even need to type.

Good.

But, I don’t even know if I have a signal in here...

Is anybody there?

Oh, what luck!

I didn’t think I could pick up a signal down here.

Unless...

You aren’t underground with me, are you?

Yes, sorry, I should have started with that.

Let’s just say I’m not in a situation that favors good manners.

My name is Michel Latrémon, and I’m a historian at the Université Jean Moulin. 

That’s in Lyons, in France.

I know that, when I tell people my profession, they often imagine an old man

with his nose buried in a book that’s just as weathered as he is.

And, believe me, that’s usually the case.

But, a few months ago, I came across a very interesting manuscript.

Do you know anything about Jean de Malemont?

It’s sort of a long story, but to sum up...

I’m in some catacombs, and I’m lost.

But I’m forgetting my manners.

Jean de Malemont was a Templar sergeant in Limoges, France, from 1304 to 1310.

When the Order of the Knights Templar was destroyed, he was taken prisoner.

But he mysteriously escaped being burned at the stake.

I picked up his trail by accident.

And I couldn’t resist the temptation to see for myself

if his tomb was really where the manuscript said it was.

Hahaha, yes.

But it’s just a name. He wasn’t a villain.

At least, I don’t think so...

Yes, exactly!

Wow, you’re not a historian, too, are you?

Hmm...

Or perhaps…You didn’t Google it, did you?

Ha ha ha!

I don’t blame you.

I’ve had a terrible stroke of bad luck.

I admit, I started my search as a complete amateur.

I’m not an archaeologist or a speleologist.

I just thought that, if it were too dangerous or complicated,

I would simply turn around and come back with a team of students.

After all, they must be good for something.

In any case…-

I contacted you by accident.

A happy accident, for me.

Maybe bothersome for you, though.

Still, I wanted to call for help with my mobile phone.

And…Well…How to explain?

I don’t like these things. I think they’re too complicated.

So, instead of dialing the right number, I probably tapped somewhere I shouldn’t have.

And I launched this Internet chat application.

But if you would be so kind as to help me...

Oh, marvelous! Thank you, thank you!

You can’t imagine how relieved I am.

Well, I’ll explain my situation.

I found these catacombs as they’re described in the manuscript.

I started exploring them, but it’s a real maze.

I wrote down the turns I took in a little notebook.

But I went through a section where water had seeped in.

The ground was covered in several inches of mud.

And with my little flashlight, I didn’t see a thing.

Anyhow. I slipped.

And my notebook fell.

Completely soaked, ink washed off...

Basically, I don’t have a map anymore.

And now I can’t get my bearings.

I’m quite lost.

Ah.

Very well.

Sorry to have bothered you.

I will try to handle things myself.

Goodbye.

I don’t have many.

I’m in a hallway that turns in front of me and behind me.

There’s an opening in the ground where I could slip through.

But I don’t know if it’s a passageway or not.

What would you do, in my place?

Okay. Thank you.

Merrily we go!

Did I tell you that I was a boy scout?

But I’m not going to start bragging, don’t worry.

Anyway, I’ll save my breath.

I’ll contact you again when I find something.
Um, are you there?

You probably won’t believe me...

I’m back to where I started.

That is to say, I’m back to the spot with the hole in the ground.

Where I asked you where I should go.

And you told me to take the hallway.

Could I have missed something, perhaps?

I have trouble believing that I could have gone in a circle.

Well. You’re probably right.

And then, nothing ventured, nothing gained.

Excuse me. I’ll stop putting you to sleep with an old scholar’s truisms.

I’ll keep you informed of my progress.
Oh, no...

There it is.

I can’t believe it.

I’m back in the same place.

And, I won’t lie to you, it’s giving me goosebumps.

How to say this?

I’m not the impressionable type.

But here, I’ve got a strange feeling.

Like I’m being watched.

Well.

I don’t really have a choice, do I?

Very well.

Courage!

I’m sorry, but I’m going to need to use both hands. I’ll put my phone in my pocket.

I’ll get back to you when I get down there.

At least, I hope so.

Back soon!
Oh, good God!

I’m in a room. But it’s nothing like the catacombs up above.

This place is older than the network of tunnels above me.

Of course, I can’t say anything for certain.

But there are architectural details that don’t lie.

And then, at the time, they built things one on top of the other.

They rarely built under existing structures.

Still, there’s something here that bothers the old historian in me.

No, no. Not to worry

Everything is alright.

It’s just that...

It’s insane!

You won’t believe me.

Hmm. You sound just like my students.

But you’ll have to excuse my sentimentality.

I’m in front of something that is incomprehensible, historically speaking.

Like I told you, the underground space where I am now

must be older than the last one.

The level that I just left dated from Malemont’s period.

But, I have here before my eyes a fresco painted directly onto the wall.

And, without a doubt, it shows, Jean de Malemont, in his Templar armor.

He is shown fighting demons and other unholy creatures that are coming out of a disc of blue light.

Malemont is holding his sword in one hand and brandishing a book with the other.

The book is glowing, and it’s represented as though it were more powerful than the Templar’s sword.

On each panel, it looks as though Jean is being followed by a black cloud.

There’s a text in Latin, under the painting.

Give me a few minutes to translate it.

Ho, ho...

Very interesting.

Excuse me. It’s just so exciting!

My intellectual nature is getting the better of me.

Especially with such a strange, long-forgotten story.

The inscription describes how Jean de Malemont was able to escape his enemies and defeat them using the book.

The book shown in the fresco.

It has a name. Unfortunately, even if it looks like Latin, it doesn’t mean anything, to me at least.

The “Libris Daemonaticaspius.”-

Hahaha, yes.

But don’t jump to conclusions. Demons were common at the time.

Especially in religious literature and the collective imagination.

Everything that the human mind didn’t understand at the time was necessarily of divine or demonic origin.

Well, anyhow...

The text explains that, in addition to other powers, the book allows it’s owner to travel to…”other places.”

I can’t manage to translate this passage clearly.

And...Oh !

It’s incredible!

According to the text, the “Libris Daemonaticaspius” should be here, in this crypt.

It’s beyond belief!

Nothing risked, nothing gained, my young friend.

But I need something to go on.

I’m not claustrophobic, but I would like to get out.

I feel more and more like I’m not alone in here.

And then...

If I go back to the university with that priceless manuscript,

it might save me from some gibes on the part of my colleagues.

When they learn how I found myself trapped in here like a fool,

they won’t hesitate to cover me with ridicule.-

Hahaha! I see you’ve caught the history bug.

Yes, it’s certainly an incredible treasure.

But more than that.

If its powers are real, I’m saved!

Well. It doesn’t matter if the book is magic or not.

I don’t have any choice but to try and find the crypt.

It would be unfortunate if I couldn’t manage to find a way out of here.

Your enthusiasm is heartwarming.

Thanks for cheering me on. I feel less alone down here.

Forward, brave companion!

Don’t worry.

Even if I’m in a strange situation, I’ve always been the careful sort.

For instance, I always check to make sure that my shoe laces are tied before I go out.

I don’t even order French fries in the cafeteria, because of my heart health.

Ah. I digress.

But thank you for your concern.

Thank you for keeping me company, it really is helpful.

Well. It’s time to make a decision.

On my left, there is a corridor leading to a staircase.

Behind me, across from the painting, there is a sort of tunnel.

The two passageways seem to be going in the same direction.

I should think that they both lead to the crypt.

The staircase has a low ceiling but it seems to be the simplest and safest way.

But something bothers me about it. I’m looking for a crypt.

Generally, one goes down into a crypt and up to get out of it.

On the other hand, the tunnel is damp and narrow.

Even if I’m not claustrophobic, I’m afraid I might slip and fall.

What do you think I should do?

So be it! Let’s climb these stairs! 

I’ll call you back when I get to…wherever it is.

Okay, time to think like a mole.

Brrrr...

It’s chilly. And wet.

If I catch rheumatism, it’s your fault.

Alright, courage!

Oh, hell.

I’m getting to old for this.

But here we are.

Actually, it isn’t very high. But...

The architects of the period seem to have though it was funny never making two steps of the same height.

At any rate, I’m in the crypt.

Well. Above it, to be exact.

I’m above the crypt, on a mezzanine.

The mausoleum looks enormous, but I’m not able to tell exactly how big it is.

The light from my flashlight is just getting lost in the darkness.

I can see the ground. It’s maybe...

Yes, about thirty feet down.

The crypt is empty; there are columns all around it at regular intervals.

And the Libris Daemonaticaspius is in the center, on a pedestal.

It’s impossible to miss. The gold leaf is reflecting the light from my flashlight.

It’s magnificent!
Yes, I see it. It’s down there.

Eh, well, I...

Oh...

What in the...

Ah!...

I...

I don’t dare move.

There’s…something in front of me.

On the mezzanine, a few feet away.

It’s... Oh, good God!

It’s the Shadow!

The one from the painting! The one that was following Jean de Malemont!

It’s all real!

Ah! Yes!

I’m running!

Ok!

I’ll climb over the railing and jump!

Aaaah!...

Okay, I...

I’m not moving.

Oh!

The floor is shaking!

Good God!

The mezzanine!

It’s collapsing, I...

...haaaa!...

<Signal lost>



Michel Latrémon has died, crushed by a pile of rubble.

He could have gotten further with your help.

Would you like to try again and make different choices?



Click "Play again" to start over.

Oh, good God!

I must have twisted my ankle.

It’s hurts like hell!

Ouch.-

Well.

I can walk.

It’s painful, but I’ll be alright.

And the good news...

is that our shadow friend didn’t follow me down here.

The other good news is that I’m in the crypt.

Next to the book!

It’s even more beautiful close up.

It looks like the cover is made of dark wood, set with gold.

The title is engraved in the center.

«Libris Daemonaticaspius»

This is really it.

I can feel my heart beating.

I hope I’m not going to end up having a heart attack.
Ah, it’s...

No, it’s moving...

It’s coming towards me!

Ahhh, I...

Ahhhhh!



...



Ahhh ha ha ha!

Hehehehehe... Hiiiiiiiiiii!

<Signal lost>



Michel Latrémon was found wandering around a few days later.

He has been committed to an institution. The poor man has completely lost his mind. 

He could have gotten further with your help.

Would you like to try again and make different choices?



Click "Play again" to start over.

When I said it was wet...

My feet are covered in water.

I’m having to walk hunched over, the ceiling is so low.

And now my shoes are wet.

Not that they’re vintage Italian leather or anything.

I only earn a professor’s salary, after all.

But that’s all I’ve got on my feet, and it’s quite uncomfortable.

I’m wondering if this was a good idea.

I’ve got water up to my waist, if you can believe it.

And I still don’t see the way out.

I think you’re right.

I’ll go back up to the room with the painting.

And try the other passageway.
Alright. I’ll keep going.

Alright. I’m back up.

My feet and my legs are ice cold, but at least I’m still breathing.

I’ll warm up by climbing these stairs.

Oh, no!

I’ve got water up to my shoulders now.

I’m having to keep my arms up to avoid getting the phone or the flashlight wet.

I’m starting to worry.

You’re right.

With the staircase, I might have reached the crypt already.

And be nice and dry to boot.

Well, I might...



Just a minute...

Alright.

I’ll keep trying.

But it’s too complicated to hold onto the phone and the flashlight.

No offense,

but I prefer seeing where I’m going to continuing our chat.

I’ll get back to you as soon as I can.

Did you hear that?

No, of course not. I’m being silly.

I...

I think there’s something behind me.

I can hear noises.

Splashing.

And something like breathing.

I’m not alone down here!

It’s getting closer.

It’s coming towards me!

Oh, good God!

I...

Easy for you to say!

Oh, no!

I don’t have a choice! I’m getting out of here!

Let’s go!

Ah, my sleeve is stuck!

I…I’m slipping!

There’s nothing to hold onto!

No!

I... Glug...

Breathe...Glug...

Air...Dro...

...

<Signal lost>



Michel Latrémon drowned to death.

He could have gotten further with your help.

Would you like to try again and make different choices?



Click "Play again" to start over.

Ah, good God!

I thought I’d never make it.

And that damn tunnel was so long.

But here I am.

I’m in the crypt.

It’s huge.

And cold.

Even if I do get this damn book, I might get pneumonia in the bargain.

And speaking of the book.

It’s here, my friend, it’s here! 

It’s in the center of the mausoleum, sitting on a pedestal.

It’s magnificent. The cover is decorated with gold plate.

The reflection lights up the room when I shine my flashlight onto it.

I’m walking towards it.

Hmmm. There’s a clasp.

Ah. It’s just a simple fastener.

Oh, what beautiful velum.

Or, could it be parchment?

I can’t see clearly in this darkness.

No matter.

Let’s see here...

Ah, there it is.

The illustration on this page represents the same blue disk as the painting.

I think it must be what Jean de Malemont used to escape.

Let me see, I...

What...

Oh, no!-

Yes, you’re right.

Best get it out of here, away from all of this humidity.

And find a nice safe corner for reading.

Humph!

Oof! It’s heavy!

No, it’s not that, I...

The Shadow. The one from the paintings.

It’s here.

In front of me.

It looks like a whirling tornado of smoke, rolling infinitely in on itself.

It’s hypnotic.

And unpleasant to look at for too long.

I don’t know what to do.

It’s just there, standing a few yards in front of me.

It’s as though it’s waiting for something.

The book, perhaps?

Yes, you’re right.

I’ll look for the passage.

There it is.

Oh, good God.

The Shadow isn’t moving but it’s reaching something out towards me!

Yes, yes!

Ah, there...

You’re right.

I get the impression that it could drive me out of my senses.

Mau...nai, ihim...

Hmm.

Strange. It doesn’t seem to be Latin.

But...

"Maunai ihim tireurepa te,

Artlu ihim tipicca non!"

The Shadow is frozen.

I mean, even the swirling of the smoke has slowed down.

Oh!

It’s getting bigger. It’s starting to expand.

And it’s becoming circular.

The smoke seems to be solidifying to form some sort of disk.

And... Wow!

It’s opening up. In the center.

The Shadow has turned into a big black disk.

And now, the center is starting to hollow. It’s forming some sort of tunnel.

It’s starting to glow.

It’s beautiful.

The light is pale blue, like a summer sky.

It’s the exit! I can get out!

Yes!

Thank you, my friend!

I’ll contact you from the other side.

Don’t worry.

I’m quite sure.

This must be the passage.

Jean must have used it numerous times.

I’ll keep my phone in my hand. Perhaps we won’t lose the signal.

I’m going in.

The closer I get, the more I feel drawn in.

As if the disk has its own gravity.

It’s hypnotic, but not frightening. Not like the Shadow before it changed.

I don’t think I’ll be able to resist much longer.

I’m being pulled in.

Thank you, thank you for your help!

I can almost see the other side.

It’s...

The pull is too strong now.

But...

It doesn’t look like...

It isn’t our world!

Noooo!

...

<Signal lost>



Michel Latrémon has disappeared into another dimension.

Despite his disappearance, you have helped him stay alive.

Who knows? Perhaps he will find his way back to our world?



Click “Return to Menu” to access Chapter 2.

You might be right.

I’ll try talking to it.

It could very well be a ghost,

or an ectoplasm,

or the spirit of Malemont...

Yes, sorry.

Excuse me, I’m getting distracted.

Let’s go on.

I’ll take a deep breath.
— Greetings, O Entity!

Shh! Quiet !

Don’t make it angry.

— I don’t wish to bother you.

— Perhaps you are protecting the Malemont treasure.

— I’m only trying to get out of here.

I think it understood.

It...

It’s moving.

It...

It’s rushing towards me!

I don’t know where...

Oh, no!

It’s wrapping around me!

It’s horrible!

Ahhhhh...!

...-

...

Ahhhh!

Ahhh ha ha ha!

Hehehehehe...

It’s blue!

Everything is blue!

A horrible, bloody blue!

Ha ha ha ha!

<Signal lost>



Michel Latrémon was found wandering around a few days later.

He has been committed to an institution. The poor man has completely lost his mind. 

He could have gotten further with your help.

Would you like to try again and make different choices?



Click "Play again" to start over.

Yes!

I’ll just get around it.
...No way out...

...I’m slipping...

Ahhhh!

My ankle!

...Can’t walk now...

It’s coming!

...Can’t stave it off...

...I...

Oh my God!

It’s got me!

Ahhh! The pain!

It’s pulling on me! It hurts!

Ahhhh!

...

<Signal lost>



The body of Michel Latrémon was found disemboweled and horribly mutilated.

No one has been able to explain why he was there, nor why his corpse was in this condition.

Would you like to try again and make different choices?



Click "Play again" to start over.

<Signal lost>



You have refused to help the professor escape from the catacombs. 

That’s not very courteous, is it?

Especially since no one has seen him since.

You’ll have his disappearance on your conscience...



Click “Play again” to start over.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Yes. I’m getting your messages.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: I’m getting your messages, but who are you?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: No, I’m at home. What do you mean "underground"?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: But, seriously, who are you? What’s this "underground" business all about?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: No. I have no idea who that is.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: What a terrible name!

Properties.MenuText: Isn’t he one of the Knights Templar?
Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: That name seems familiar. Wasn’t he a Templar?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: What’s happened to you? It seemed like you need help.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Why did you contact me? What do you expect me to do?

Properties.MenuText: Sure, I’d be happy to help.
Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: I’d like to help if I can, but I don’t think there’s much I can do.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Sorry, I don’t have time for this. You’d be better off calling the police.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: What options are open to you right now?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: I don’t know if I can really help, but can you tell me what you want me to do?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Goodbye. And good luck

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Try to follow the hallway. That seems like the most logical option.

Properties.MenuText: Climb down into the hole in the ground.
Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Maybe it will lead you out of there faster.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Yes, Michel. I’m still here.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: What is it? Have you found something?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: You must have missed a turn-off. Go back.

Properties.MenuText: Try the opening in the ground.
Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Forget about it. Try climbing down the hole instead.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Have you found something?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Don’t tell me. You’re back where you began?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: You have to go down through that opening in the ground.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Michel, are you alright? You’re not hurt, are you?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: What’s going on? Have you found something?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: What’s so surprising, Michel?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Are you sure you didn’t hit your head on the way down?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Well, have you been able to read it all? What’s it about?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Don’t string me along, Michel! Tell me what you’re reading!

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: It has the word “daemon” in it. That kind of sounds like “demon”, right?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Does the text say anything else?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Michel, what is it?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: What have you found now?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: You have to find it! It’s a priceless historical artifact.

Properties.MenuText: Are you going to use it?
Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: You think it can help you get out of there with magic. Is that what you’re thinking? You must be crazy!

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: You’re right. You have to explore the crypt. There’s got to be an exit there.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: It’s possible, but it’s risky. Be careful.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: I’d suggest the stairs. It’s the safest choice.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: I would take the tunnel. I don’t think the stairs will lead to the crypt.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: What are you seeing?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Do you see the book? Can you get to it?

Properties.MenuText: What are you going to do?
Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: What are you going to do?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Can you reach it?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Michel? Is everything okay? Are you alright? Answer me!

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Michel, answer me!

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: What is it? What do you see?-

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Run! Don’t just sit there! Run for it!

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Jump, it’s the only way!

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Don’t budge! Don’t move a muscle. Don’t make any noise.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Go back the way you came. That’s the smart thing to do.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Try to keep going. It would be silly to stop now.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Keep moving forward if you can. It can’t go on much longer.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Take a break. Let’s think about this for a second.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Don’t panic.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Get out of there!

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Go ahead, open it and look for the part that talks about how to escape.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Just take it, you’ll have time to read it later.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: What is it? Did you damage the book?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Michel? What’s happening? Talk to me!

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Don’t waste time, Michel. Find the passage about how to escape.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Maybe it isn’t dangerous. Try to communicate with it.

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Get out of there! Quick!

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Don’t panic!

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Don’t look at it!

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Go ahead, Michel! And when you get out of there, call me!

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Be careful! What makes you so sure that it’s really what you think it is?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Go ahead. Talk to it, dammit!

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Don’t waste any more time! Talk to it!

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: Great introduction!

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
Properties.Text: "Entity", for real?

Properties.Speaker: 0x100000000000157
